EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 2009 RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM UPDATE

A Risk Management Program has been implemented at Arkema Inc., Houston, Texas production facility to redue the risk of accidental releases of hazardous materials.  This Risk Management Plan summarizes the management, administrative, procedural and tehnological controls that work together to minimize the risk to the community of hazardous chemical releases.

ARKEMA POLICIES FOR HEALTH, ENVIRONMENT AND SAFETY

Risk management and safety have een important concerns at Arkema for many years.  The Risk management Plan formalizes and documents thhese activities.  Arkema is committed to conducting its operations in a safe, responsible manner and to reduce risks to health and the environment.  Commitment to health, environment, and safety (HES) starts with the CEO.  Senior management routinely dedicates time to review HES Matters.  Emphasis on safety is carried through to the facility level, where the Plant Mananager and the Safety Committee regularly review safety performance, take corrective actions and strive for continuous improvement.  The success of Arkema's HES programs include policies, procedures, standards, and guidance materials designed to fulfill Arkema's commitment to health, environment and safety.  These materials include Risk Management Program guidance to held our facilities prevent and/or reduce the risk of accidents.  This facility is covered by Title V of the Clean Air Act.

FACILITY IDENTIFICATION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES IN COVERED PROCESSES

The Arkema Houston facility is located at 2231 Haden Road, Houston, Texas.  The facility manufactures mercaptans and sulfides.  Certain substances used and produced within the facility are regulaed substances under 40 CFR 68, the EPA Risk management Program (RMP) rule.  Thse substances are present at or above the minimum threshold for RMP applica bility and include:  Carbon Disulfide (CS2) 2,540,000 pounds and Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) 13,000 pounds.  Carbon Dis

ulfide is a by-product of Hydrogen Sulfide production.  Hydrogen Sulfide is manufatured on site to produce mercaptans.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Arkem Houston facility has an accidental release prevention program in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases.  This program is designed to address the requirements of 29 CFR 1920.119, Process Safety management (PSM) and the EPA Risk Management Program.  This prevention program addresses processes that handle regulatd substances.  The accidental release prevention program includes the following components and activities.

In depth hazard analyses are completed every five years by qualified personnel usig tecniques approved under the OSHA PSM Standard of 29 CFR 1920.119:  Written operating procedures are used for training and directing the work of oprtors, who receive refresher training every three years;

Operators, mechanics and contractor personnel are qualified trained in the general hazards in the facility, and informed of any temporary situations affecting safety;

A management of change system is in place to ensure that process-oprating changes are managed safely,

Critical equipment is inspected on a planned, periodic basis to ensure proper operating condition,

Pre-start up review are performed to ensure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied piror to starting new or modified equipment,

Incidents are investigated and actions taken as part of a continuous iprovement effort,

Routine audits are conducted to ensure that safe practices are being followed,

Storage vessels are designed and constructed in accordancw with American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) pressure vessel standads using industry-standrd atrials of construction,

As part of the echanica Integrity program, pressure vessels and transfer lines are inspected and tested accordingn to the American Petroleum Institute Standards,

The use of trained

operators who monitor level indicators and metering devices are trained to prevent overfilling,

Relief valves and administrative controls are designed to prevent over-pressure,

Access to the facility is restrictrd trhough security barriers and trained security personnel, tereby monimizing the risk to the tanks of vehicular damage or sabotage; and

A safety permitting system is used to ensure routine and non-routine work is carried out after identification and implementation of safe work practices.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The Arkema Houston plant has a written plan of action in place regarding the implementation of employee participation.

The Arkema Houston Plant consults with its employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of process hazards analysis and on the development of the process safety management plan.

The Arkema Houston Plant provides employees and their representative access to process hazards analysis and to all other required information.

This systematic approach to process safety involves the facility employees.  Management and facility personnel strive for continuing improvements in accident reduction.  The training, qualification standards, and safety awareness of our opeations, maintenance, and emergency response personnel are key elements in reducing and mitigating accidents.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no off-site releases of carbon disulfide or hydrogen sulfide that have resulted in the on-site inuries during the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

A written Emergency Response plan is maintained at the facility.  The plan was developed in cooperation with civil authorities and was coordinated with the community emergency response plan.

The emergency response plan includes procedures for notifying civil authorities and the public in the event of an incident.  The plan also includes documentation of proper first aid and medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposure; procedur

es fo rthe use of emergency response equipment and for tis inspection and testing.  The plan also includes a description of the training program for all employees in relevant emergency response procedures and procedures for review and update, as appropriate, of the response plan, to reflect changes at the facility and to ensure that employees are informed of these changes.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Chemical safety has been a part of the working culture at the facility for many years.  Chemical exposure risks to employees and the public have  been minimized through ongoing internal risk reduction efforts as well as retulatory requirements.  Planned improvements to the existing safety program include; implementation of behavior based safety and additional accident investigation training.  Additional planned facility improvements include upgrades in the process control systems of a production unit and increases security measures.
